# Cloud computing ‚òÅÔ∏è {background-color="#2d4563"}

## What is cloud computing?

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 22px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Cloud computing is the [on-demand delivery]{.alert} of computing resources through a cloud services platform via the internet with [pay-as-you-go pricing]{.alert}
- Cloud computing has increased in popularity in recent years because it offers many advantages
  - [Scalability, flexibility, and cost-efficiency]{.alert}
- There are three main types of cloud computing services: [IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS]{.alert}
- The most popular cloud computing platforms are [Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform (GCP)]{.alert}, the "Big Three"
- They are so widely used that Amazon's AWS is the [most profitable division]{.alert} of the company
  - Although it is only 15% of their total sales, they account for more than 50% of their profits (~28 bi)
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/amazon.png){width=100%}

Source: [GeekWire](https://www.geekwire.com/2025/amazons-quarterly-profits-soar-to-a-record-20-billion-but-cloud-growth-comes-up-short/)
:::
:::
:::
:::

# Why should we care about cloud computing? ü§î {background-color="#2d4563"}

## Imagine you are opening a business...
### Traditional approach

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 28px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
1. Estimate supply and demand
2. Estimate infrastructural needs
3. Purchase and deploy infrastructure
4. Install and test your system
5. Offer your services to clients
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
- Infrastructure is [very expensive]{.alert}: 
  - Hardware costs (Dell charges [50k for its least expensive server](https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/cty/pdp/spd/poweredge-r6715/pe_r6715_tm_vi_vp_sb)) 
  - Real estate costs 
  - Cooling system, power bill 
  - A few systems engineers 
  - Redundancy for high reliability
- It takes time and deploy the infrastructure
- [What if the estimations were wrong?]{.alert}
:::
:::
:::

## Imagine you are opening a business...
### Cloud approach
:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 28px;"}

1. Choose one or more cloud services providers
2. Deploy your systems on the cloud
3. Offer your services to clients
4. Pay for what you use

:::{style="margin-top: 40px;"}
:::

| **Traditional process**       | **With Cloud Computing**      |
|-------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| ‚ùå High investment risk       | ‚úÖ Reduced risk               |
| ‚ùå Long time-to-market        | ‚úÖ Shorter time-to-market     |
| ‚úÖ Manages own data           | ‚ùå Trust the vendor?          |
| ‚úÖ Completely in control      | ‚ùå Dependant from a specific vendor? |
:::

## Case study: Animoto

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- [Animoto](https://animoto.com/): Lets users create videos from their own photos/music
- Auto-edits photos and aligns them with the music, so it "looks good"
- Built using Amazon EC2+S3+SQS 
- Released a Facebook app in mid-April 2008 
- More than [750,000 people signed up within 3 days]{.alert}
- EC2 usage went [from 50 machines to 3,500 (x70 scalability!)]{.alert}
- [No way they could have done this with traditional infrastructure]{.alert}!
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/animoto.jpg){width=100%}

Source: Jeff Bezos' talk at Stanford in 2008
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Case study: The Washington Post

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 23px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- [Hillary Clinton's official White House schedule released to the public]{.alert}
- 17,481 pages of non-searchable, low-quality PDF
- Very interesting to journalists, but would have required [hundreds of man-hours to evaluate]{.alert}
- Peter Harkins, Senior Engineer at The Washington Post: "Can we make that data available more quickly, ideally within the same news cycle?"
- Tested various Optical Character Recognition (OCR) programs; estimated required speed
- Launched [200 EC2 instances]{.alert}; project was completed within nine hours using 1,407 hours of VM time ($144.62)
- Results available on the web only [26 hours after the release]{.alert}
:::

# Cloud computing services ‚òÅÔ∏è {background-color="#2d4563"}

## Cloud computing services

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
- [SaaS (Software as a Service)]{.alert}: 
  - Software is hosted on a cloud and accessed via the internet as a complete application
  - You don't have to worry about updates, security, or maintenance
  - You (usually) pay a subscription fee (monthly or yearly)
  - Examples: [Gmail](https://gmail.com), [Office 365](https://www.office.com), [Salesforce](https://www.salesforce.com)
- [PaaS (Platform as a Service)]{.alert}:
  - Provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications without the complexity of building and maintaining the infrastructure
  - Usually, the platform offers a series of APIs
  - You pay for the platform and the resources you use (e.g., storage, bandwidth)
  - Examples: [Google App Engine](https://cloud.google.com/appengine), [AWS Elastic Beanstalk](https://aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk), [Heroku](https://www.heroku.com)
:::

## Cloud computing services

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 28px;"}
- [FaaS (Function as a Service)]{.alert}:
  - Allows you to run code without provisioning or managing servers
  - You pay for the time your code/function runs
  - Examples: [AWS Lambda](https://aws.amazon.com/lambda), [Google Cloud Functions](https://cloud.google.com/functions), [Azure Functions](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/functions)
- [IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service)]{.alert}:
  - Provides virtualised computing resources over the internet
  - You can rent virtual machines, storage, and networking
  - You pay for the resources you use
  - Examples: [AWS EC2](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2), [Google Compute Engine](https://cloud.google.com/compute), [Azure Virtual Machines](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/virtual-machines)
:::

## What is virtualisation?

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Suppose Alice has a machine with 4 CPUs and 8 GB of memory, and three customers: 
  - Bob wants a machine with 1 CPU and 3GB of memory 
  - Charlie wants 2 CPUs and 1GB of memory 
  - Daniel wants 1 CPU and 4GB of memory
- [What should Alice do?]{.alert}
- Alice can sell each customer a [virtual machine (VM) with the requested resources]{.alert}
- From each customer's perspective, it appears as if they had a [physical machine all by themselves (isolation)]{.alert}
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/virtualisation.png){width=100%}

More about [virtualisation](https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/virtualization/what-is-virtualization)
:::
:::
:::
:::

## What is middleware?

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Middleware is software that [connects two separate applications]{.alert}
- This is software we rarely see, but which is [essential for the functioning of the internet]{.alert}
- For instance, software than handles [authentication, authorisation, and encryption]{.alert}, drivers that [connect to databases]{.alert}, and software that [handles messaging]{.alert}
- [Amazon SQS](https://aws.amazon.com/sqs), [Apache Kafka](https://kafka.apache.org), and [RabbitMQ](https://www.rabbitmq.com) are examples of middleware
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/middleware.avif){width=100%}
:::
:::
:::
:::

# AWS services üõ†Ô∏è {background-color="#2d4563"}

## Amazon EC2 - Elastic Compute Cloud

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 25px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Amazon EC2 is a web service that provides [resizable compute capacity]{.alert} in the cloud
- It's designed to make web-scale cloud computing easier for developers
- You can launch instances with a [variety of operating systems (mainly Linux)]{.alert}
- Which means that, for the most part, [you can use bash and run any software you want from the command line]{.alert}
- You can also use a [GUI interface]{.alert}, but it is not necessary
- You can use EC2 to host a website, run a database, or run a machine learning model
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
- However, please be [mindful of the costs!]{.alert}
- You pay for the instances you use, and the [costs can add up quickly]{.alert}
- Per-second (or per-hour) billing
- Data transfer [not]{.alert} included!
- Persistent storage [not]{.alert} included!
- Scaling [not]{.alert} included!

:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/ec2meme.jpg){width=100%}
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Cloud storage
### Amazon S3 - Simple Storage Service

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 23px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Amazon has three main storage services: [S3, EBS, and EFS]{.alert}
- S3 is a web service that provides [object storage]{.alert} through a web interface
- You can store data in [buckets]{.alert}, which are like folders
- Data are distributed across a minimum of [three availability zones]{.alert}
  - 99.9999999% durability (nine nines!)
- You can set up [lifecycle policies]{.alert} to automatically move data to cheaper storage classes
  - [Standard, Intelligent-Tiering, Glacier, Glacier Deep Archive]{.alert}
- You can also set up [versioning]{.alert} to keep multiple versions of an object (works like `git`)
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/s3.png){width=100%}

<https://aws.amazon.com/s3/>
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Cloud storage
### Amazon EBS - Elastic Block Store

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 23px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- EBS is a web service that provides [block storage]{.alert} volumes for use with EC2 instances
- The difference between S3 and EBS is that EBS is [block storage]{.alert}, while S3 is [object storage]{.alert}
  - [Block storage is like a hard drive]{.alert}, while object storage is like a file system
- Why would you use it? [Mainly for SQL files]{.alert}
  - Low-latency, high-performance storage for frequent access
- You can attach EBS volumes to your EC2 instances
- You can also take [snapshots]{.alert} of your volumes for backup (like `git` again!)
- Up to 16 TB per volume
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/ebs.webp){width=100%}

<https://aws.amazon.com/ebs/>
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Database services
### Amazon RDS - Relational Database Service

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 23px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Amazon RDS is a web service that makes it easy to set up, operate, and scale a [relational database]{.alert}
- You can choose from [six popular database engines]{.alert}:
  - [Amazon Aurora, PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, Oracle, and SQL Server]{.alert}
- You can also use [Aurora Serverless]{.alert} to automatically scale your database
- It's a managed service, so you don't have to worry about [backups, patches, or updates]{.alert}
- It works well with another AWS service called [Athena]{.alert}, which allows you to query data in S3 using SQL
- You can also use [Redshift]{.alert} for data warehousing, and [DynamoDB]{.alert} for NoSQL databases
:::

:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{style="text-align: center;"}
![](figures/rds.png){width=60%}

<https://aws.amazon.com/rds/>
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Amazon SageMaker

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 22px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Finally, let's talk about [Amazon SageMaker]{.alert}
- SageMaker is a fully managed service that allows you to build, train, and deploy machine learning models at scale
- It has several pre-configured models, such as [TensorFlow, PyTorch, and Scikit-learn]{.alert}
- You can also bring your own models too, and use [Jupyter notebooks]{.alert} to train them
- Lots of other models available in the [AWS Marketplace]{.alert}, and you can also use [SageMaker Studio]{.alert} to manage your projects
- Machine Learning: application services 
  - Comprehend (for NLP) 
  - Rekognition (Visual Analysis) 
  - Translate 
  - Polly (text-to-speech)
:::

:::{style="text-align: center;"}

## Managing an AWS account

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 25px;"}
- The first thing you should do is [to use a billing alarm]{.alert}
  - You can set up a billing alarm to notify you when your bill exceeds a certain amount
  - This is very important, as costs can add up quickly
- Go to <https://console.aws.amazon.com/costmanagement/>
- In the navigation pane, choose [Billing Preferences]{.alert} (scroll down to the bottom)
- By [Alert preferences]{.alert} choose [Edit]{.alert} 
- Choose [Receive AWS Free Tier Alerts]{.alert} 
- Choose [Save preferences]{.alert}
- Then go to <https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/billing/home#/budgets/overview>
- Choose [Create budget]{.alert}, choose a [Zero spend budget]{.alert} template, add your email, then click [Create budget]{.alert}

## Download the transcription

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
- Now you can download the transcription file in JSON format
- Click on the [Download]{.alert} button, and save the file
- Now open the file in VS Code or any text editor
- You will see the transcription in JSON format, with the text and the timestamps
- We only need the text, so let's extract it
- Find the `results` key, and then the `transcripts` key
- The text is in the `transcript` key, so copy it
- We will then go to [Amazon Comprehend](https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/comprehend/home?region=us-east-1) and analyse it
:::

## Analyse the transcription

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
:::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}
- Now let's go to [Amazon Comprehend](https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/comprehend/home?region=us-east-1)
- Search for `Comprehend` in the search bar
- Click on [Launch Amazon Comprehend]{.alert}
- Scroll down and paste the text in the [Input data]{.alert} box
- Click on [Analyze]{.alert}
- And that's it! You will see the results in the [Insight]{.alert} box!

## Delete the transcription job and S3 bucket

:::{style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 26px;"}
- Now that we are done, we can delete the transcription job and the S3 bucket
- Go to [Amazon Transcribe](https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/transcribe/home?region=us-east-1) again and select the transcription job
- Click on [Delete job]{.alert} and confirm
- Then go to [Amazon S3](https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/s3/home?region=us-east-1) and select the bucket
- First you need to delete the objects inside the bucket. Just select the file and click on [Delete]{.alert}
- Type "permanently delete" to confirm
- Then click on the bucket, type the bucket name, and click on [Delete bucket]{.alert}
:::
